story:
UPDATE 18th OCTOBER- new page count - now 64 pages of awesome Ninja Action 

This story is set in the kingdom of Bichon and follows the adventures of Nini, a young Ninja in training with a happy-go-lucky demeanour and a knack for helping out people in need. Along with her trusty dog Loyal Leo, Nini and Leo set off to find and track down the dastardly devil who stole the Bichon Crown.  

The world in which this story is set revolves around dogs, in-fact their whole culture is about dogs.  I mean who doesn’t love dogs?, cat people I suppose, but anyway that’s a different story.

Who is Daddy Duder?

Well I’m a happily married father of 2 beautiful daughters who lives in Tokyo, Japan, and this is my first comic book. 

This comic was inspired by a father’s love for his family, and my daughter Nina was my main inspiration for the character Nini.  Obviously my daughter’s not a Ninja, but I hope when she grows up she has the same character traits as the heroine Nini, strong and willing to help out all people in need.     

The perks dude, lets talk about the perks.

I’ve got some sweet perks fit for a Ninja, as well as the usual stuff.  How about getting your hands on a One of a Kind Limited Edition Cover, or ever wanted to be a baddie in a comic book? well you can.  Also for you dog lovers out there, how would you like to get your dog immortalised in print?  Check out these perks and more, and if they catch your eye grab one whilst you can.

Let’s check out some Art.

 

Now it’s time to talk seriously, Lets talk about money. 

So what do I need?, well any money raised will go on 2 things:

The first is printing costs, and the second is social media advertising.  I was hoping to raise a minimum of $500.  As this is my first comic I need to raise more awareness to sell more copies, both for the first issue and future issues,  I’ve already planned the story for the first 12 issues, and I’m hoping that I can build upon my first campaign and over time gain many supporters. 

As my daughter is the inspiration for my comic, I want to write a story that she can proud of, and I hope the reader can feel the love, care and attention that I’ve put into the story.  And besides this world can always do with another fun story to warm people’s hearts, as its too serious already.

So that’s what you’re gonna get if you back this comic, a fun exciting read, well I think so anyway and I hope you do too.

OK, so what’s risk in backing my campaign?

No risk, If I took the money and run, I’d never be able to look my little Nini (my daughter Nina) in the face again, as I’d be letting her down as well, so that ain’t gonna happen.  I have finished about 40% of the comic and am on target for completion in April 2020.

Whats the chance that I’ll finish the project late?

Well to be truthful, I plan to finish the comic around the end of April 2020, but I’m a busy father of 2 beautiful daughters aged 2 and half and 2 months, and if you don’t know kids are really hard work.  There might be a slim chance of the comic running late, but I think I’ve allowed myself enough time so the delay would be minor at best.

So there you have it Nin-Nin Nini, I look forward to finishing my comic, and hope that both my family and customers both love my comic.

Thank you very much for checking out my campaign, I hope you’re as excited to read my comic as I am to write it.   I hope to hear from you soon. Bye bye.

Bye the way, If you wanna back my campaign but can’t no worries, but If you could spread the word on social media using the wonders of modern technology that’d be great, oh and remember to use the Indiegogo share tool if you back the campaign.

story:
USAssassin Book I: Old Habits... is an original graphic novel from the writer/co-creator of the smash hit, Graveyard Shift Volume I & II, Mark Poulton with art from Mike McMahon (Graveyard Shift/Lonestar). 

When former government, super agent, Joe Knight, takes a job with a private security firm, he thinks his days of superheroics are far behind him. However, when the team of metahumans he was hired to train double cross him and take his family hostage, he realizes old habits are hard to quit! This 80 page graphic novel was originally offered to backers of Graveyard Shift Volume II as a stretch goal. For those who missed out, this is now your chance to get the book! This campaign will be the only way you can get the book with a bookplate signed by the creators Mark Poulton and Mike McMahon, as well as Slither and Bazooka Dog co-creator, Chase Poulton (Pizza Tree, SeaDog and Codename: Killswitch).  The book is 100% completed and back from the printer. These are our limited copies left over from the Graveyard Shift campaign so these will go out immediately after the campaign ends. 

This campaign is limited to only 300 copies. Once they are gone, the campaign ends. However, there are plenty of great add-ons available including original art, sketches and even an USAssassin hockey jersey with your name and number on the back!

story:
Stretch Goal #1

Having exceeded our goal to print The Partners 5: Hostile Heartroot, we are now campaigning to meet our first stretch goal: $15,000 USD

Reaching this goal will allow us to increase the size of the first press run and give us additional funds to promote and advertise our book on social media platforms worldwide.

If we meet this stretch goal every contributor to my campaign will receive two limited-edition bookmarks and a button with their book order.

Please help us get the word out by sharing our campaign link on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram and email: https://igg.me/at/thepartners5

The Mastermind

Umar Mycka is a seasoned horticulturist specializing in the removal and disposal of Poison Ivy. He has invested much of his life in educating young and old alike in the dangers of this toxic plant.

The Graphic Novel

The Partners 5: Hostile Heartroot was published free online for 100 episodes. Dubbed “Where Horticulture Meets High Adventure”, The Partners 5 is based on Umar’s own crew of colleagues and the effects that pollution is having on our environment – specifically the way it’s changing the poison ivy plant itself.

The Partners 5: Hostile Heartroot is full of monsters, giant mantises, action, adventure and educational facts.

It’s a truly original piece of comic book fiction.

The Goal

To raise funds for the first edition printing of: The Partners 5: Hostile Heartroot, by pre-selling the graphic novel. 

Production

We estimate three weeks for production and three weeks for the book shipment to arrive from our overseas printer. 

Shipping

Your order will be shipped by United States Postal Service within two weeks of our receipt of the overseas shipment. The Partners 5: Hostile Heartroot is only available to addresses in North America: $8 to anywhere in the USA, $12 to anywhere in Canada.

Disbursement of Funds

After platform fees and credit-processing fees have been deducted from the total, we will use the remaining funds to print The Partners 5: Hostile Heartroot. If we exceed our goal, the additional funds will allow us to order a larger print run, and afford us an advertising budget to bring this graphic novel to the reach of a wider audience.

The Risks

Risks are minimal. The graphic novel is complete and ready for printing. Once we have met our goal and the funds are released, the graphic novel will be sent to the printers and put into production.
story_txt:
Stretch Goal #1
Having exceeded our goal to print The Partners 5: Hostile Heartroot, we are now campaigning to meet our first stretch goal: $15,000 USD
Reaching this goal will allow us to increase the size of the first press run and give us additional funds to promote and advertise our book on social media platforms worldwide.
If we meet this stretch goal every contributor to my campaign will receive two limited-edition bookmarks and a button with their book order.
Please help us get the word out by sharing our campaign link on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram and email: https://igg.me/at/thepartners5
The Mastermind
Umar Mycka is a seasoned horticulturist specializing in the removal and disposal of Poison Ivy. He has invested much of his life in educating young and old alike in the dangers of this toxic plant.

The Graphic Novel
The Partners 5: Hostile Heartroot was published free online for 100 episodes. Dubbed “Where Horticulture Meets High Adventure”, The Partners 5 is based on Umar’s own crew of colleagues and the effects that pollution is having on our environment – specifically the way it’s changing the poison ivy plant itself.
The Partners 5: Hostile Heartroot is full of monsters, giant mantises, action, adventure and educational facts.
It’s a truly original piece of comic book fiction.


The Goal
To raise funds for the first edition printing of: The Partners 5: Hostile Heartroot, by pre-selling the graphic novel. 


Production
We estimate three weeks for production and three weeks for the book shipment to arrive from our overseas printer. 


Shipping
Your order will be shipped by United States Postal Service within two weeks of our receipt of the overseas shipment. The Partners 5: Hostile Heartroot is only available to addresses in North America: $8 to anywhere in the USA, $12 to anywhere in Canada.



Disbursement of Funds
After platform fees and credit-processing fees have been deducted from the total, we will use the remaining funds to print The Partners 5: Hostile Heartroot. If we exceed our goal, the additional funds will allow us to order a larger print run, and afford us an advertising budget to bring this graphic novel to the reach of a wider audience.



The Risks
Risks are minimal. The graphic novel is complete and ready for printing. Once we have met our goal and the funds are released, the graphic novel will be sent to the printers and put into production.

story:
Overview

Demons Vol. 3 is the finale of the story of Detective Ace Carter that was set up in Vol. 1 and 2. Leviathan has defeated and dismantled the F-666 and is not hunting for "The Light," the last piece to the puzzle for him to take unlock hell. Meanwhile Ace Carter has found "Inferno" (aka Hell), and is searching for "The Heart of the Demon." This is it! The FINALE! The end of the story! Join Ace Charter, Chloe Waters, and John the Revelator, as they take a final stance against evil.

DEMONS Vol. 3: Inferno - 120+ page Graphic Novel

Click here for a FREE DOWNLOAD of Issue #1 >>> https://bit.ly/2CyOPYq

Click here for a FREE PREVIEW of Vol. 2 >>> https://bit.ly/2HPQwXh

The story of DEMONS ends in Volume 3!

 

Here are the first FOUR pages!

 

 

Here is an assortment of pages!

 

Thank you everyone for the support!!

story:
Do You Like Religion and Comics?

Have you ever wondered about why you have faith? Or wanted to know more about what that part of your life could mean? 

"Why Faith?" is a wondrous, full-color comics anthology, jam-packed with stories from creators of all faiths, identities, and backgrounds. Edited by Jack Holder, and featuring some of the greatest creators in the business, these 30 stories bring to bear the question of why one should (or should not) have faith, and how it truly changes the very nature of life.

Why "Why Faith?" 

My background is in how religion and the arts work together. This is because for many years I did not know how to express what I found compelling about church, and yet so contradictory.

The way I found my way back to God was through art. Going to plays, and hiking, and devouring book after book after book. I could see glimpses of God in every page, every sight and sound. It was only once I stepped outside of church, that I could find why I needed to come back.

What these creators have done is try to answer the question of why (or why not) to believe in a certain way. Doing so with art, with compassion, and with a clarity that I believe is inspired by Grace.

This anthology is, in part, for our children as well as for us. As we grow up, we try to determine for ourselves what God has in store for us. Or even if there is a God. Having this book here allows that child to ask questions, and find answers.

For anyone who is still searching and discontented by what one sees, I say that “Why Faith?” is here for you. We are inviting all to have that still-small courage to ask the question of why. You may not find the same answer that I did. Your truth may turn you down a path I had never considered before. And that makes you beloved.

If you would like to know more, please click the link here to be taken to a 30-page preview, completely free. Read our works, see the ideas that these creators bring to life, and come back and enjoy the rest of the anthology.

Thank you for reading, and I hope you have a blessed day.

Our Creators

What I cannot express enough is how each of these amazing contributors approached this question. We have had transformative experiences in our own faith journeys, simply by allowing ourselves to try and answer the question. In backing this campaign, you help us bring to life a new way of considering faith. One that brings us together in celebrating our differences and our similarities in the search of the ultimate question of why.

 

What We Need & What You Get

The $10,000 goal is to create a true print run. The book is drafted with all of the stories, but what we really need is the capital to make this come to life. 

The money will go towards our creators, printing and shipping our rewards to you.

What can you get?

  • Art Book - Alongside the anthology, we are also putting forth a 60-page Art Book directly from artists. Each page is created by a new artist, featuring their own exploration into the question of Why Faith?
  • Being written into Jody Lynn Nye's next book.

Who Are We?

Trina Robbins – “Poppa”

In 1970, Trina Robbins produced the very first all-woman comic book, "It Ain't me, Babe."  In 1972 she was one of the founding mothers of "Wimmin's Comix," the longest-lasting women's anthology comic book. (1972 - 1992) 

In the mid-1980s, tired of hearing publishers and editors say that girls don't read comics and that women had never drawn comics, she co-wrote (with catherine yronwood) "Women and the Comics," the first of what would become a series of histories of women cartoonists.  She has been responsible for rediscovering previously forgotten early women cartoonists like Nell Brinkley, Tarpe Mills, Barbara Hall, and Lily Renee. 

In 2013 Trina was inducted into the Will Eisner Comic Book Hall of Fame.  In 2017 she was inducted into the Wizard World Hall of Legends, and at the San Diego comic convention she received the Eisner award for editing the two-volume reprint collection of the complete “Wimmin’s Comix.”.

And, oh yeah, in 1986 she became the first woman to draw a Wonder Woman comic book.

Wm Paul Young – “The Power of True Fiction”

Author of the novels, The Shack, Cross Roads, and Eve, and recently released non-fiction Lies We Believe about God, was born a Canadian and raised among a stone-age tribe by his missionary parents in the highlands of what was Netherlands New Guinea (now West Papua).  He suffered great loss as a child and young adult, and now enjoys the “wastefulness of grace” with his growing family in the Pacific Northwest.

Facts never tell real stories.  The journey has been both incredible and unbearable, a desperate grasping after grace and wholeness, the pain of trying to adjust to different cultures, of life losses that seemed too staggering to bear, of living with an underlying volume of shame so deep that it constantly threatened any sense of sanity, of dreams not only destroyed but obliterated by personal failure, of hope so tenuous that only the trigger seemed to offer a solution. A few facts also do not speak to the potency of love and forgiveness, the arduous road of reconciliation, the surprises of grace and community, of transformational healing and the unexpected emergence of joy

Issey Fujishima – “Behind the Deep Shadow”

Issey Fujishima is a Japanese German comic writer based in Melbourne. His first book “The Reign of God—A Gospel Story” (2017) is an intense graphic novel that explores the passion and message of the historical Jesus. He has contributed essays about Christian spirituality to Inheritance Magazine and a comic about identity in the Australian zine Comic Sans. Find more about him and his work at www.thereignofgod.com and instagram: @issey.fujishima

Mary Bellamy – “Purpose”

Womanthology and Womanthology: Space as an artist, colorist and editor of the sketchbook. I have worked on several licensed properties like IDW Publishing’s My Little Pony: FIM comic as a cover artist, a colorist for Nightmare Before Christmas: Zero’s Journey with Tokyopop and Disney Manga and a sketch card artist for several highly known properties like Marvel, DC Comics, Adventure Time, Rick and Morty, Ghostbusters and more. I’ve worked in animation on The Drew Carey Green Screen Show and for Titmouse Animation. I also have two long running graphic novel series Faux Facts – The Truth Can Be Strange and Ah Heck!!

Russell Nohelty – “The Current”

Russell Nohelty is a USA Today bestselling author, publisher, and speaker. He runs Wannabe Press (www.wannabepress.com), a small press that publishes weird books for weird people. Russell is the author of Gumshoes: The Case of Madison’s Father and My Father Didn’t Kill Himself, along with the creator of the Ichabod Jones: Monster Hunter, Gherkin Boy,

Pixie Dust, and Katrina Hates the Dead graphic novels. He also edited the Monsters and Other Scary Shit and Cthulhu is Hard to Spell anthologies, which both raised over $25,000 on Kickstarter. To date, Russell Nohelty has raised over $100,000 on Kickstarter across eight projects. You can check out his books for yourself by joining his mailing list at www.russellnohelty.com/mail, where he’ll send you a collection of his books for free.

Michael Norwitz – “Day of Rest”

Michael has written for punk zines ( The Trouble with Normal; Masochistic Submission ) and philosophical journals ( Philosophy Now ). His comic works have appeared in Possession (http://possessioncomic.com ) from Markosia Enterprises, Rock Is Not Dead from 11th Dimension Press, and Sci: The Jewish Comix Anthology from AH Comics.

Maria Photinakis – “A Necessary Adaptation”

Maria Photinakis is an illustrator and comic book artist in the greater Boston area. Her published work includes a comic on cosplay in the anthology  "SubCultures" and on the first computer virus in the successfully Kickstarted science anthology "Boundless." Her own
published work includes the scifi horror "Red Flag." She is currently working on a biographical memoir about grief and the immigrant experience in America called "Benedictions." Her website is https://www.photinakis.com

Jeannie Harmon – “Gold Medalist”

Jeannie Harmon graduated from Winthrop University with a degree in Illustration in 2011.  Jeannie works full-time as a graphic designer while also freelancing in comics and illustration.  She has done work for various projects, including for the Doubleclicks as one of 50 women artists featured in their "Women Know Math" music video (womenknowmath.com), illustrations for Dorenda Truesdale's children's book "Geolindin: Just Twyin' to Unnerstand," and more.  Jeannie also creates Ruby Red, an ongoing webcomic about trust, fear, and superpowers (rubyredcomic.com).  More information about Jeannie's work can be found at pjeanniejean.com.

Sho Uehara – “Creation Checklist”

Illustrated Exclusive Calgary Expo covers for BOOM! Studios line of comics for Adventure Time, Fiona & Cake, and Regular Show. Editorial illustrations for the Calgary Herald's "Swerve Magazine" line. Illustrated a children's book last year for Inhabit Media Press focusing on Bowhead Whales. Creator/Cartoonist for a self-published Fairy Tale Graphic Anthology titled "Wishless", and for a new comic book titled "Repose" that debuted at the Calgary Expo

Chad Colpitts – “Creation Checklist”

Chad Colpitts is the writer and self-publisher of two on-going indie titles, “The Streaker” and “B-Movie Garbage”

Sarajea Martin - "By Their Fruits Shall You Know Them"

Sarajea Martin is a creator and teaching artist living in Minneapolis. Her autobiographical works on disability and mental illness explore themes of loss, resilience, and finding the joy and humor in everyday life. She believes fervently in the healing power of art. Her work can be found at www.foundbysara.com

Liz Young - "Sigils"

Liz Young is a queer autistic cartoonist from Massachusetts who loves to learn about different cultures and philosophies.  She enjoys writing and drawing comics that reflect on her experience, whether the stories are autobiographical or fictional.  In her comic, “Sigils,” Liz explores the importance of self love with her discovery in pagan faith.

A. A. Rubin – “Rebbe Claus”

A.A. Rubin lurks in the shadows. He surfaces occasionally to publish stories in a variety of mediums. His work has appeared in Kyanite Press, Serious Flash Fiction, Pif Magazine, and Constellate Literary Journal. His story "The Substance in The Shadow" has been named a Fiction War finalist, and his story "White Collar Blues" was nominated for the Carve Magazine/Mild Horse Press online short fiction award. His debut graphic novel, Night Prowler: In The Cross Hairs will be published by Golden Bell Studios. Mr. Rubin holds a BA in Writing/Literature from Columbia University, and an MA in Teaching of English from Teachers College Columbia University. A mild mannered public school teacher by day, he roams the streets at night as a vigilante crime fighter. He does not believe in secret identities. He wants the criminals to know his true face. He can be reached on Twitter and Facebook as @thesurrealari.

Tyler Carpenter – “Rebbe Claus”

Tyler Carpenter is an award-winning SPJ Editorial Cartoonist and comic book writer and artist. He is the host of the YouTube show “Draw and Talk” and creator of many comics including “Demons,” “The Hardline,” and “Entity.” You can follow him on social media at @tyler_c_world and make sure to subscribe to his YouTube channel! 

Travis Gibb - "Barter" 
Travis has worked in comics off and on for 15 years. He has write stories for various titles including but not limited to Negative Burn, Nerd Nation Radio, Space Coast Comixx, Government Bodies, OGN Dogdays and self publishes his own book BROKE DOWN AND FOUR DEAD BODIES. He views himself as a Marketplace Minister and is very active in his local church scene.  He is also very richly blessed to have a wonderful wife, two awesome daughters and a newborn son. He also own a successful web design company that has been around for 10 years. www.brokedownandfourdeadbodies.com

Jameson Hampton – “The Dweller on the Horizon”

James Hampton is a brand new comic creator, debuting in Why Faith! They got their start in comics as a critic for WWAC. They've also had their poetry featured in Moonchild Mag and Rhythm & Bones Lit and they were a contributor to the Uncaged anthology of D&D modules.

Matt H. Taylor – “The Dweller on the Horizon”

Matt H. Taylor is a cartoonist and illustrator debuting with the Why Faith anthology. He has been self-publishing the RMS Titanic inspired webcomic 'Admiral' since August 2017. He resides in Buffalo with his partner, their two cats and has a weird obsession with old boats.

Cyndi Norwitz – “Let the Beet Go On”

Most of Cyndi’s works are poems, which she has performed to audiences large and small on both coasts.  Her published works include poetry, essays, and newspaper articles.  She also taught academic writing to undergraduates.  This is her first comic.  Cyndi lives in the San Francisco Bay Area where she makes organic soap and is writing a middle-grade Jewish fantasy novel. 

James Hachey - "The Last Day Warrior"

James Hachey artist/creator of numerious titles spanning over a 40 year period, he started doing a fanzine (amateur magazine) in 1978 called Concepts,..then he gravitated to producing religious art for the Pentacostal church (called the first united Pentecostal church) this he did for over three years,..then he returned to mainstream comics joining a local fanzine titled the Sorcerer stone presents circa 1982-1984 he met his long time friend and co-creator artist,.. Tim Fallon who after joining Jim's book the Destructors of Evil,..they collaborated on many a cover together producing 12 issues in total over a three year period, when the book ended they all parted ways (Jim assembled over a dozen talented individuals) which went on to producing their own books,..then Jim contacted his good friend Tim Fallon who was working on a magazine of his own titled Manga Ganda ( modeled after the old E.C.comics) after talking to him about his magazine Jim described his story to Tim (Jim wrote a short story in the first issue called Scoffers Beware) first printing was done in 1999, then Jim mentioned redoing his characters the Destructors with Tim suggesting him to pencil it while he inked it,..and adding writer Paul Beale to the credits. the rest is comic history. Jim has included his books along with a few pages from his book Manga Ganda series

Jason Remick – “What Lies in the Depths”

Jason Remick has been involved and contributed work to a variety of projects spanning film and videogames. Remick found his calling in comics where he has been writing and illustrating the 'Organic Fast Foods' web comic for the past 4 years."

Eddy Hedington – “The Time Between”

Eddy Hedington is a writer and letterer who resides in Tacoma, WA with his wife and 4 kids. He's recently started his own comic label, Grit City Comics, who's planning on releasing their first anthology "Monster Mash-up" later in 2019. He is hard at work with releasing his first ongoing series titled "The Dunwich Boys", an adventure series set within the Lovecraft universe. You can follow his progress at eddyhedington.com and at gritcitycomics.com

Melissa J Massey – “Neighbors”

Melissa J. Massey is an artist and writer making stories inspired by both shonen action series and shoujo magical romance, both of which she loved reading growing up in north New Jersey. Currently, she is the creator of the ongoing comic Black Ball, a 1920s magical murder mystery, and a freelance artist on several upcoming projects. She was also featured as an artist in Cthulhu is Hard To Spell, a Lovecraftian anthology edited by Russell Nohelty. Her story in Why Faith?, "Neighbors", was based on her own experiences of meeting people from different religions throughout her life and the enrichment it brought to her own beliefs. 

Grace Desmarais – “Meeting Joan”

Grace Desmarais is a French-Canadian illustrator and cartoonist. Currently, Grace lives in a cozy corner of Western Massachusetts, and spends most of her time drawing comics in her Northampton studio. Most of her work is rooted in or around subjects like art history, dis/ability, and hilariously personal experience. On the off chance Grace is not drawing she tends to be playing Dungeons & Dragons, or enjoying a craft beer.

Greg Wright - "Professor Faust"

Greg Wright has written several comics, including the pulp-fueled Wild Bullets series from the Michigan Comics Collective; the Source Point Press ongoing comic series Monstrous—a comic book mash-up of classic monsters fighting steam-powered robots; and the Source Point Press Holliston graphic novels, based on Adam Green’s cult favorite horror-comedy TV show. 

His comic series Monstrous is currently being developed into a live-action television show in Hollywood.  He earned his Ph.D. in American Literature and Film from Michigan State and has taught screenwriting, film, literature, humanities, and composition.  His academic work and his award-winning fiction have appeared in a variety of journals.

If he had a castle with a secret passage, he’d probably tell everybody and make it just a regular passage.

Visit his Amazon page, Facebook, or Twitter to learn more about Greg.

Aaron Williams – “Cycles”

Aaron William is an artist and the host of the podcast Comics Manifest, a show that launched at the end of 2016 and focuses on the craft of making comics, the people who make them, and their journey that turned this thing that they love to do, into something that supports them and in some cases their families. Not very many hobbies can become something that can pay for itself let alone turn into a career and anthologies are the perfect place for new voices to speak and be heard.

'Cycles' is Aaron’s first published piece. In his own words “I was so excited when I got Jack's email telling me that I was accepted for the anthology and for the topic at hand. My piece for this book is pretty short at only 4 pages, but it proved to be a challenge to present this idea I had about faith in just that much space. I think what I came out with does the job pretty well.” 

Golan Moskowitz - "Part Hole

Golan Moskowitz studied studio art and psychology at Vassar College before completing a PhD in Jewish studies at Brandeis University, where he also earned a joint MA with women's and gender studies.  His visual art and scholarship investigate how queer and ethnically marginalized subjects become who they are in relation to intergenerational family dynamics, history, memory, and contemporary culture. Currently a visiting scholar at the Hadassah-Brandeis Institute, Golan has taught at Smith College and Tufts University and has published scholarly pieces on Maurice Sendak and grandchildren of Holocaust survivors.

What if you don't entirely fund?

  • The funds will still go towards our creators, and a smaller run.

The Impact

  • What this anthology has shown is how our differences in faith can unite us just as much as it can divide. Thirty different, and in many cases antithetical views on what faith is have come together in the hopes of a dialogue. 
    • Backing this project allows us to continue making comics that help strengthen our dialogue with each other.

Risks & Challenges

I have personally funded three of my own crowdfunded books before, and am fairly familiar with the model. But we realize that this is a major anthology, and that it may take extra time than anything before.

We have already spoken with churches, synagogues, and other religious organizations about getting "Why Faith?" in their hands, as well as other investors. However, the major step here is making sure that we can get the books out to everyone. If we do not fund completely, 

I can't contribute, BUT I really want to help!

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean that you can't help. Please let everyone and anyone know about this project. Use the Indiegogo share tools! Review the preview, share it as well.

Thank you all.

Michael Norwitz – “Day of Rest”
Michael has written for punk zines ( The Trouble with Normal; Masochistic Submission ) and philosophical journals ( Philosophy Now ). His comic works have appeared in Possession (http://possessioncomic.com ) from Markosia Enterprises, Rock Is Not Dead from 11th Dimension Press, and Sci: The Jewish Comix Anthology from AH Comics.
Maria Photinakis – “A Necessary Adaptation”
Maria Photinakis is an illustrator and comic book artist in the greater Boston area. Her published work includes a comic on cosplay in the anthology  "SubCultures" and on the first computer virus in the successfully Kickstarted science anthology "Boundless." Her ownpublished work includes the scifi horror "Red Flag." She is currently working on a biographical memoir about grief and the immigrant experience in America called "Benedictions." Her website is https://www.photinakis.com
Jeannie Harmon – “Gold Medalist”
Jeannie Harmon graduated from Winthrop University with a degree in Illustration in 2011.  Jeannie works full-time as a graphic designer while also freelancing in comics and illustration.  She has done work for various projects, including for the Doubleclicks as one of 50 women artists featured in their "Women Know Math" music video (womenknowmath.com), illustrations for Dorenda Truesdale's children's book "Geolindin: Just Twyin' to Unnerstand," and more.  Jeannie also creates Ruby Red, an ongoing webcomic about trust, fear, and superpowers (rubyredcomic.com).  More information about Jeannie's work can be found at pjeanniejean.com.

Sho Uehara – “Creation Checklist”
Illustrated Exclusive Calgary Expo covers for BOOM! Studios line of comics for Adventure Time, Fiona & Cake, and Regular Show. Editorial illustrations for the Calgary Herald's "Swerve Magazine" line. Illustrated a children's book last year for Inhabit Media Press focusing on Bowhead Whales. Creator/Cartoonist for a self-published Fairy Tale Graphic Anthology titled "Wishless", and for a new comic book titled "Repose" that debuted at the Calgary Expo
Chad Colpitts – “Creation Checklist”
Chad Colpitts is the writer and self-publisher of two on-going indie titles, “The Streaker” and “B-Movie Garbage”
Sarajea Martin - "By Their Fruits Shall You Know Them"
Sarajea Martin is a creator and teaching artist living in Minneapolis. Her autobiographical works on disability and mental illness explore themes of loss, resilience, and finding the joy and humor in everyday life. She believes fervently in the healing power of art. Her work can be found at www.foundbysara.com
Liz Young - "Sigils"
Liz Young is a queer autistic cartoonist from Massachusetts who loves to learn about different cultures and philosophies.  She enjoys writing and drawing comics that reflect on her experience, whether the stories are autobiographical or fictional.  In her comic, “Sigils,” Liz explores the importance of self love with her discovery in pagan faith.

A. A. Rubin – “Rebbe Claus”
A.A. Rubin lurks in the shadows. He surfaces occasionally to publish stories in a variety of mediums. His work has appeared in Kyanite Press, Serious Flash Fiction, Pif Magazine, and Constellate Literary Journal. His story "The Substance in The Shadow" has been named a Fiction War finalist, and his story "White Collar Blues" was nominated for the Carve Magazine/Mild Horse Press online short fiction award. His debut graphic novel, Night Prowler: In The Cross Hairs will be published by Golden Bell Studios. Mr. Rubin holds a BA in Writing/Literature from Columbia University, and an MA in Teaching of English from Teachers College Columbia University. A mild mannered public school teacher by day, he roams the streets at night as a vigilante crime fighter. He does not believe in secret identities. He wants the criminals to know his true face. He can be reached on Twitter and Facebook as @thesurrealari.
Tyler Carpenter – “Rebbe Claus”
Tyler Carpenter is an award-winning SPJ Editorial Cartoonist and comic book writer and artist. He is the host of the YouTube show “Draw and Talk” and creator of many comics including “Demons,” “The Hardline,” and “Entity.” You can follow him on social media at @tyler_c_world and make sure to subscribe to his YouTube channel! 
Travis Gibb - "Barter" Travis has worked in comics off and on for 15 years. He has write stories for various titles including but not limited to Negative Burn, Nerd Nation Radio, Space Coast Comixx, Government Bodies, OGN Dogdays and self publishes his own book BROKE DOWN AND FOUR DEAD BODIES. He views himself as a Marketplace Minister and is very active in his local church scene.  He is also very richly blessed to have a wonderful wife, two awesome daughters and a newborn son. He also own a successful web design company that has been around for 10 years. www.brokedownandfourdeadbodies.com
Jameson Hampton – “The Dweller on the Horizon”
James Hampton is a brand new comic creator, debuting in Why Faith! They got their start in comics as a critic for WWAC. They've also had their poetry featured in Moonchild Mag and Rhythm & Bones Lit and they were a contributor to the Uncaged anthology of D&D modules.
Matt H. Taylor – “The Dweller on the Horizon”
Matt H. Taylor is a cartoonist and illustrator debuting with the Why Faith anthology. He has been self-publishing the RMS Titanic inspired webcomic 'Admiral' since August 2017. He resides in Buffalo with his partner, their two cats and has a weird obsession with old boats.
Cyndi Norwitz – “Let the Beet Go On”Most of Cyndi’s works are poems, which she has performed to audiences large and small on both coasts.  Her published works include poetry, essays, and newspaper articles.  She also taught academic writing to undergraduates.  This is her first comic.  Cyndi lives in the San Francisco Bay Area where she makes organic soap and is writing a middle-grade Jewish fantasy novel. 
James Hachey - "The Last Day Warrior"
James Hachey artist/creator of numerious titles spanning over a 40 year period, he started doing a fanzine (amateur magazine) in 1978 called Concepts,..then he gravitated to producing religious art for the Pentacostal church (called the first united Pentecostal church) this he did for over three years,..then he returned to mainstream comics joining a local fanzine titled the Sorcerer stone presents circa 1982-1984 he met his long time friend and co-creator artist,.. Tim Fallon who after joining Jim's book the Destructors of Evil,..they collaborated on many a cover together producing 12 issues in total over a three year period, when the book ended they all parted ways (Jim assembled over a dozen talented individuals) which went on to producing their own books,..then Jim contacted his good friend Tim Fallon who was working on a magazine of his own titled Manga Ganda ( modeled after the old E.C.comics) after talking to him about his magazine Jim described his story to Tim (Jim wrote a short story in the first issue called Scoffers Beware) first printing was done in 1999, then Jim mentioned redoing his characters the Destructors with Tim suggesting him to pencil it while he inked it,..and adding writer Paul Beale to the credits. the rest is comic history. Jim has included his books along with a few pages from his book Manga Ganda series
Jason Remick – “What Lies in the Depths”
Jason Remick has been involved and contributed work to a variety of projects spanning film and videogames. Remick found his calling in comics where he has been writing and illustrating the 'Organic Fast Foods' web comic for the past 4 years."
Eddy Hedington – “The Time Between”
Eddy Hedington is a writer and letterer who resides in Tacoma, WA with his wife and 4 kids. He's recently started his own comic label, Grit City Comics, who's planning on releasing their first anthology "Monster Mash-up" later in 2019. He is hard at work with releasing his first ongoing series titled "The Dunwich Boys", an adventure series set within the Lovecraft universe. You can follow his progress at eddyhedington.com and at gritcitycomics.com

Melissa J Massey – “Neighbors”
Melissa J. Massey is an artist and writer making stories inspired by both shonen action series and shoujo magical romance, both of which she loved reading growing up in north New Jersey. Currently, she is the creator of the ongoing comic Black Ball, a 1920s magical murder mystery, and a freelance artist on several upcoming projects. She was also featured as an artist in Cthulhu is Hard To Spell, a Lovecraftian anthology edited by Russell Nohelty. Her story in Why Faith?, "Neighbors", was based on her own experiences of meeting people from different religions throughout her life and the enrichment it brought to her own beliefs. 
Grace Desmarais – “Meeting Joan”
Grace Desmarais is a French-Canadian illustrator and cartoonist. Currently, Grace lives in a cozy corner of Western Massachusetts, and spends most of her time drawing comics in her Northampton studio. Most of her work is rooted in or around subjects like art history, dis/ability, and hilariously personal experience. On the off chance Grace is not drawing she tends to be playing Dungeons & Dragons, or enjoying a craft beer.
Greg Wright - "Professor Faust"
Greg Wright has written several comics, including the pulp-fueled Wild Bullets series from the Michigan Comics Collective; the Source Point Press ongoing comic series Monstrous—a comic book mash-up of classic monsters fighting steam-powered robots; and the Source Point Press Holliston graphic novels, based on Adam Green’s cult favorite horror-comedy TV show. 
His comic series Monstrous is currently being developed into a live-action television show in Hollywood.  He earned his Ph.D. in American Literature and Film from Michigan State and has taught screenwriting, film, literature, humanities, and composition.  His academic work and his award-winning fiction have appeared in a variety of journals.
If he had a castle with a secret passage, he’d probably tell everybody and make it just a regular passage.
Visit his Amazon page, Facebook, or Twitter to learn more about Greg.
Aaron Williams – “Cycles”
Aaron William is an artist and the host of the podcast Comics Manifest, a show that launched at the end of 2016 and focuses on the craft of making comics, the people who make them, and their journey that turned this thing that they love to do, into something that supports them and in some cases their families. Not very many hobbies can become something that can pay for itself let alone turn into a career and anthologies are the perfect place for new voices to speak and be heard.
'Cycles' is Aaron’s first published piece. In his own words “I was so excited when I got Jack's email telling me that I was accepted for the anthology and for the topic at hand. My piece for this book is pretty short at only 4 pages, but it proved to be a challenge to present this idea I had about faith in just that much space. I think what I came out with does the job pretty well.” 
Golan Moskowitz - "Part Hole
Golan Moskowitz studied studio art and psychology at Vassar College before completing a PhD in Jewish studies at Brandeis University, where he also earned a joint MA with women's and gender studies.  His visual art and scholarship investigate how queer and ethnically marginalized subjects become who they are in relation to intergenerational family dynamics, history, memory, and contemporary culture. Currently a visiting scholar at the Hadassah-Brandeis Institute, Golan has taught at Smith College and Tufts University and has published scholarly pieces on Maurice Sendak and grandchildren of Holocaust survivors.
What if you don't entirely fund?
The funds will still go towards our creators, and a smaller run.


The Impact
What this anthology has shown is how our differences in faith can unite us just as much as it can divide. Thirty different, and in many cases antithetical views on what faith is have come together in the hopes of a dialogue. Backing this project allows us to continue making comics that help strengthen our dialogue with each other.


Risks & Challenges
I have personally funded three of my own crowdfunded books before, and am fairly familiar with the model. But we realize that this is a major anthology, and that it may take extra time than anything before.
We have already spoken with churches, synagogues, and other religious organizations about getting "Why Faith?" in their hands, as well as other investors. However, the major step here is making sure that we can get the books out to everyone. If we do not fund completely, 

I can't contribute, BUT I really want to help!
Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean that you can't help. Please let everyone and anyone know about this project. Use the Indiegogo share tools! Review the preview, share it as well.
Thank you all.

story:
Oi! SOLSTICE

 

Link to Oi! Volume 1

Link to 10 page SOLSTICE preview

 

THE STORY SO FAR

      Oi! Tales of Bardic Fury is a historic fantasy comic set in ancient Ireland that tells the story of Bryan the bard. Before graduating at the great Bardic College in Tara, Bryan must complete a one year work placement in a tiny coastal village in the north that never heard music before called Oi. After a rocky start in his first performance, Bryan eventually found his footing in town as a performer. Under the mushroom-addled oversight of Starseal the town druid,  Bryan starts a band with Servius the Roman slave, Aideen the hurling captain and her little sister Rhiannon the selkie. As music and songs began to spread through Oi, the villagers became happier and the town more prosperous
        After accidentally summoning a pod of orcas and leading a revolt against the oppressive tax collectors of Tara, Bryan became a legend in the village. Solstice begins 3 months after volume 1 ends on the night of winter solstice. But as Oi celebrate the new season with a concert and feast, The Druidic Order of Tara bureaucrats plot their revenge. Our bardic heroes will soon have to learn the hard way that If you want to party, you got to pay the piper...

 

The Books

Both books are available during this campaign. Solstice is the newest chapter of Oi! picking up after Volume 1 ends. It is 48 pages and will include bonus behind the scenes concept art and pinups. Solstice will be perfect bound 7"x10"x with a matte laminated cover and black and white manga style interior pages. First edition risograph printings of Oi! Volume 1 are also available. These books are works of art, printed in woad colored ink on paper designed to make each page physically feel like a vintage concert poster. This boutique 5.5"x 7.5" 136 page tankobon manga sized first edition was originally printed in a run of 1,000. There are only 40 copies left and they're available for sale for this campaign.


You can purchase Oi! Volume One and my other graphic novels as Add-On perks during check out.

 

Where I am with work on Oi! SOLSTICE

I write, draw, ink color and letter all of my comics as well as design the print files. It is a lot of work but I love doing it so that you can get the best comic I'm capable of served up to you. I currently have finished the cover and back cover art as well as 16 pages of story and have the rest scripted and storyboarded. I should be able to get the remaining pages finished in about 2 months.

Perks-wise I am keeping this Indiegogo campaign simple so I can focus on the book and keeping shipping and fulfillment as simple and quick as possible.

 

About the Artist

I am a cartoonist with 7 years of experience in drawing, creating and publishing independent comics. I have exhibited and sold my work at comic cons around the world including MCM Glasgow, MCM London, Thoughtbubble UK, Wondercon, San Diego Comic Fest, Fan X Salt Lake, Los Angeles Comic Con. and Las Vegas Comic Con. Having successfully crowdfunded three previous graphic novels Oi! Tales of Bardic Fury Vol 1, Purrvana, and A Song of Mice and Fur, I'm excited to start a campaign for Oi! SOLSTICE. I founded OMEOW COMICS with the goal of self-publishing entertaining comic stories that encourage people to think for themselves. I love creating high quality entertaining comic books for your enjoyment and with your help I can continue to keep doing so.

Perks

With this campaign I am trying to keep the tiers as simple as possible to make sure that everything goes quickly with the shipping and print production.

If you have any questions about perks or custom commissioned drawings or anything else campaign related, please to message me here on indiegogo or by email at dnl.desosa@gmail.com

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot contribute to the campaign financially, I cannot emphasize enough how much sharing the link to this campaign with your friends over social media will help bring this project to life. Thank you!

story:
Short Summary

A publisher of "how-to" guides in comic book form, designed to help ESOL and adult literacy learners acquire valuable life skills. The idea came about when publisher and writer Nick Xylas was on the Outset Bristol course, which helps people to set up their own businesses.  He had a background writing short informational articles for various websites and magazines, and his classmates suggested he combine this with his love of comics.

What We Need & What You Get

I have asked for $3000 as an initial target, to cover artists' salaries and printing costs for 100 copies of the first title in the series, Jhaakob Comes to Earth, which sets up the characters and also serves as a guide to the UK immigration and asylum system. Any additional funds raised will go towards printing extra copies and creating further titles.

The Impact

Parthenia Comics are designed to help some of the most vulnerable members of society (eg immigrants, asylum seekers, prisoners and adults with learning difficulties) learn some of the skills that many of us take for granted, in order that they can integrate better into society and become more self-reliant.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't afford to donate at this time, please post a link to this page on your blog, Facebook Page, Twitter account or whatever, in order to get the word out to as many people as possible.  Positive comments also help raise the profile of this campaign on Indiegogo.

story:
Please click the link to check a 5 page preview of the graphic novel.

http://www.crimsonarcher.com/hammer-city-guardian/

My name is Houston K. Hughes. A few years ago I started a young adult novel series called 'THE GUARDIANS of HAMMER CITY'. Hammer City is set in a world almost identical to yours and mine, except for one small thing: masked vigilantes exist.

HAMMER CITY GUARDIAN is a graphic novel set in the world of the book series, but is made to stand on its own (while remaining in continuity). It is the story of 14 year old Harper Triller and his life that has recently been turned upside down. His best friend has been gone for months, his aunt is wheelchair bound due to a violent attack, and his mentor is in prison. Oh, and he is in love with his former babysitter (17 year old Jamie), while trying to fight crime in his spare time with nothing more than a domino mask, gloves, and a hoodie.

All the money raised by this campaign will go toward paying the artist (except printing costs). This project is a labor of love for me, and I can't wait to show these characters and this story to the world!

story:
Montreal, seven years after a zombie infestation. Bike-forged weapons and roof-bound communities have kept people safe. But for how long?

Z'lsle is a zombie apocalypse comic book series that will be told in 3 volumes by illustrated by Lateef Martin and co-written by Lateef Martin and Isabelle Duguay.  This campaign will fund the first volume composed of 6 issues.

The original concept was created by Lateef and illustrator Dan Buller who felt they had something to add to the genre. Where The Walking Dead continues after the credits of your average zombie film, Z'Isle asks: what would life be like seven years later?

Upcycling. The key to survival.


CHECK OUT SOME MORE ART HERE 

Wha--Really? Another Zombie Story? What's Different about Z'Isle? 

Most zombie stories are about people trying to escape the problem. In Z'Isle, the people of Montreal have decided to live with it. As a result new systems have been put in place. Bike paths shelled in the carcasses of city buses stretch for miles. Maniacal Larpers have become hired swords.  Zip lines and quick bridges create roofways between buildings. The Framework is place. But you fellow Z'Islanders, have the opportunity to help fill it out! YOU are a crucial part of what makes Z'Isle come alive!

Franco Proietti, the first contributor of our campaign. Yes, you can look as cool as that.

 Along with a descriptive paragraph of your character (and yes, you can be a member of the undead!) such as an origin story, or a recounting of your personal story through a main character in Z'Isle

-a brief appearance

-a reoccurring role throughout the first 6 issues

-a main role, a pivotal character in the world of Z'Isle!

Join us and explore how Montrealers have learned to live with the problem and build towards a new future.

Remember: keep to the roofs


Matteo, one of the characters you may cross paths with in Z'Isle


What We Need & What You Get

We require $6000 (CAD) to create the first 6 issues that compose Volume 1 of a 3 Volume trilogy! (that's 18 issues for the Count Draculas out there)

The lionshare will go to Lateef Martin to write and draw all six issues of Z'Isle over the span of a year with an issue coming out every two months. It will also cover the cost of some of the the brain-exploding rewards coming your way including:

  • Prints of the first 6 issues of Z'isle
  • Buttons, stickers, fridge magnets and posters
  • Replicas of bike-forged weapons from the world of Z'Isle such as the gear axe and gear mace
  • 4x4 acrylic paintings of a scene from Z'Isle
  • 'Survival' gear from Xtreme Paraphilia
  • A Z'Isle-themed longboard by Revolutionary Longboards

*shipping not included


Languages

Z'Isle will be available in French and English. Just ask.


But Wait! That's Not All!

The holidays are fast approaching. But why run around looking for that perfect gift when it's right here? We now offer Z'Islander Certificates of Survival!  When you purchase an award level we will send you a certificate.  Not only does it look awesome, but it lists all the rewards you purchased and has a space to fill in any name you wish and looks a little something like this:

We will deliver these bad boys at the beginning of December!

We will also be launching the official Z'Isle website where we will feature a blog, previews of artwork, and concept art of characters based on the people who have contributed to our campaign. Other tidbits and surprises will be added to the site as things grow that will involve you and your stories fellow Z'Islanders! 


Stretch Goal #1

If we reach $7000 EVERY contributor will receive a Z-'Ring Fridge magnet-approx 3 inches, A Z'Isle classic!


Infect The Masses

Spread the virus--er, I mean word about Z'Isle! You can help us by just letting your friends know about Z'Isle and that they can help build the world with their own personal stories.

Other tidbits and surprises will be added to the site as things grow that will involve you and your stories fellow Z'Islanders! Stretch Goal #1
If we reach $7000 EVERY contributor will receive a Z-'Ring Fridge magnet-approx 3 inches, A Z'Isle classic!



Infect The MassesSpread the virus--er, I mean word about Z'Isle! You can help us by just letting your friends know about Z'Isle and that they can help build the world with their own personal stories.

story:
Bear witness as the most feared pirate ever to sail the seven seas, Blackbeard himself, and his crew of ruthless cutthroats face off against the most revered King to ever rule over Great Britain, King Arthur and his Knights of the Round Table.

On a quest from God, King Arthur has dispatched three of his most trusted Knights to search for the Holy Grail. Unfortunately for the King, he is not the only one that seeks the sacred prize.  The King of the Britons will be tested like never before. He will put his life on the line for the sake of his country and for the sake of his people.

The infamous pirate Blackbeard is on the hunt for the ultimate power, power that will allow him to rule over the seven seas for all of time. But, his reward won't come easy. Blackbeard will have to use all of his cunning and brutality if he has any hope to defeat some of the greatest warriors that the world has ever seen.

Blood will be split but which hero will prevail?

Available original pages: https://www.recklesshero.com/portfolio-item/kni...

This project will be our tenth comic and our third crowdfunded comics. The comic itself is complete and is on the way to the printers.

With the situation with COVID-19 there are greater risks than would normally be present. This is most likely to have an impact on the production and the postage times. We have built in a bit of extra time into the plan to take account of this.

We have also reduced the number of bulky items we would normally offer to help with the postage and try to ensure that as many reward tiers as possible fit through standard letterboxes.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Any support you can give is always appreciated, if you can't back it sharing it with friends and family that may be interested is just as good. Thank you.

story:
Part Machine, Mostly Man

I'm a Senior at IUPUI(Indiana University-Purdue University) and I want to make my senior project the best, but I need your help.

I've got the pages mostly done but I need funding for printing, distribution, and creating an infrastructure for when I graduate. I'm not going to have access to the same facilities and would like to emulate my current layout for ensured future success.

Here is a breakdown of the 700 level:

Funding

Obviously I would like to stay with Kablam for printing since they'll more than likely do a better job.

So what does that mean?

My goal is 2,000.00:

  • I'm looking at printing about 100 or so books. The books will be 39 pages, 14 page script, some alternative art and a thank you page. The format will be graphic novel style and I'd like to share as much of my journey with you as possible.
  • No matter what you give me I want to make sure you have a digital copy so you can read my work.
  • Ultimately I want to purchase a large media scanner since my work is 11"x17" and normal printers won't accommodate this size.
  • If I get 700 dollars I will purchase a Large Media Scanner.
  • If I get 2000 dollars I will purchase a Cintiq so I can start working digitally.
  • Any excess will be going towards the reward structure to ensure value.

    The Impact

After attending several conventions here in Indiana I've ignited my passion for illustrations and sequential narrative. To that effect I want to have the best showing for my senior project.

Additionally I want to show my process via this video and the inclusion of my script to show how the final project and outline may vary. 

    Risks & Challenges

    Since this is my first comic this whole process is a learning one. I hope that my positive energy and passion will guide me towards being more perceptive and give me the experience to do better, bigger, stronger the next time.

      Other Ways You Can Help

      Make sure to share this indygogo page and link to my other pages. There will be more updates and videos to come!
      Comments welcome!

story:
What is this? "Parallel" is an online graphic novel I'm currently working on. It will be serialized and most likely will be 200-300 pages long when completed, spanning six or seven chapters. I will be publishing "Parallel" for free on smackjeeves and the first chapter will be available to read around mid-March. When the entire story is finished I will be publishing it as an eBook for Kindle and other eBook readers. If there is enough demand I will look into publishing it in print in the future.

What's it about? Takeshi Ueda and Ayuka Hagiwara lived together as children in a group home for foster children. They chanced upon a doorway to another world and were taken under the wing of the enigmatic queen of that world, Elodie.


Twenty-five years later, Takeshi and Ayuka have long since been separated and fallen out of touch. Each has succumbed to the emptiness that befell them in their childhood. One night they are pulled back into the realm they believed was a dream, which has been plunged into chaos. Elodie has been kidnapped and her power usurped by a ruthless organization, headed by a man known as "The Nobleman". Reunited, Takeshi and Ayuka must help the citizens loyal to Elodie find her so peace can be restored to their world.


What's the money for?

I'd like to be able to finish "Parallel" in a timely manner and keep a minimum amount of time between chapter updates. However, in order to do that I need a serious equipment upgrade. That means a new desktop computer as I'm still using my 2002 G5 Power PC (go ahead, point and laugh) and Manga Studio EX barely functions on it. I'm also going to need a tablet with an LCD screen. So far I've narrowed it down to the Wacom Cintiq 12w or the P-Active XPC1910. Why would I need something like that? Well, I have no team working with me. Not yet anyway. So I will get things done a lot quicker if I'm able to use a tablet that lets me draw on it like I would paper. These two things together will consist of at least half the amount of money I'm raising.

I'm planning on bringing "Parallel" to AM2 in Anaheim and Anime Expo in Los Angeles this year. I will need to purchase space in Artist's Alley at both conventions and pay for 4-day passes to Anime Expo for myself and one of my volunteers. I will be printing the first chapter of "Parallel" as a teaser and also making prints and posters as well as working on other merchandise related to the project.

Last but not least, I want to build a website that will be a main hub for everything related to "Parallel" and the other comic project I will start production on after "Parallel" is finished. 

If there is any money left, I will put it toward having "Parallel" published in print.


What's in it for me?

If you take a gander over to this side ------->...

I've got plenty to offer in return for your generosity, ranging from a simple thank you on my website to sneak previews of the first chapter before its release to the public to signed prints and original character sketches.


What happens if you don't get the full amount you're asking for?

I will be going forward with "Parallel" regardless of how much money I raise. It will just take longer for me to finish it.

I totally want to read this but I can't contribute any money. Is there anything else I can do?

Obviously securing funding is very important in order for "Parallel" to come to fruition. But getting some visibility in the community is just as important! So if you're really interested in "Parallel", please, please, PLEASE share this page with everyone you know. Post it on Facebook, Tweet it, Tumbl it or promote it in any zany, creative way you can come up with (just don't break the law or hurt anyone :)). Also, you can follow me on Twitter to receive updates on the project.


EDIT: "Parallel" now has a Facebook page. :)

story:
1001 Sundays is my web comic full of strange, surprising, awkward, funny, and reflective stories about me and my mysterious, ageless, wonder Dad.  

 

Just check us out:

 

A little over a year ago, I decided to create 1001 Sundays as an online comic that doesn't use any panels, frames, or pages to go from scene to scene.  Instead, you can read each story in the form of a big continuous scrolling picture where characters and scenes flow into each another in a milky dreamlike way.

Over the past 52 weeks I've told five stories this way, and the response has been really overwhelming and exciting, and I'm super grateful to everyone who's liked my comic so far!

So here I am, a year later, wanting to turn my scrollable adventures into books. 

Why?

As I kept drawing 1001 Sundays, every issue became more visually challenging than the last.  I wanted to make each story look and feel unique, and the artwork became so insanely detailed that I wanted to create something tangible for anyone who enjoys the art to keep.

I was also eclipsed by how long these stories have gotten.  If printed, each would would be at least 50 to 100 feet long!

 

So...

I'd like to create five full color, dazzling graphic novels for the five issues I've released online so far:

Meet Roxanne Barley, your seamstress of story (and my alter-ego). In this inaugural installment of 1001 Sundays, Roxanne tells us how she came to be - not her physical birth - but her incredible identity.  And she owes it all to a woman who died-- because she wouldn't drink her own pee.

 

Every once in a while you might find yourself on a colorful, geometric, sparkly, dazzling drive through a bright, sunny forest without a care in the world.  But how often do you find psychotic truckers and helpless turtles on those drives?  Believe it or not, for Roxanne, this misadventure is just latest in a long line of traumatic testudine tragedies.  In this issue, Roxanne takes you through the woods and into the past on a suspenseful and eye-grabbing journey that will leave you thankful that you don't have too many turtles in your life.

 

"This is the story about a lisserd.  A lisserd that died."  So begins Roxanne's tale of mischief, adventure, and reptilian woe.  In this hand-inked issue you'll find tropical getaways, cities swirling in smoke, and rambunctious reptiles all told through the typewritten text of a 7-year-old Roxanne.

 

Can a three year old ruin Christmas?  If that three year old is Roxanne Barley, she sure can.  In this wild suspenseful tale, written in rhyme, Roxanne describes how the care, planning, and dedication of her PapPap is threatened by the curiosity of a rambunctious Roxanne. 

 

Last but not least...  I would also like to create a book for this last story that will finish out the year!  This story hasn’t been told yet on 1001 Sundays, but – keep following the site and watch this story unfold:

Some people have lucky dice.  Roxanne Barley has two teeth she plucked from the jaw of a dead horse she found on the beach when she was three.  Roxanne doesn't usually believe in the supernatural, but whenever she travels she takes her lucky horse teeth with her.  And when she hasn't, things have a tendency to get a little bumpy.  Join Roxanne on her first trip outside the United States on a visit to Israel, bringing to the Holy Land the only objects she's ever felt were sacred--her lucky horse teeth.

 

Each book will be printed in full color and signed by yours truly! 

There will also be 25 Limited Edition, signed, boxed sets!  Inside these boxed sets will be all five of the printed books as well as two special surprises!  {Shhh!  I’m not telling what they are!}

Hopefully, with your generous donation, I can publish these stories as hard copies!  I’ll also provide you with some bedazzled keepsakes for your donation!  Make sure to check them all out.

 

Now let me express my endless gratitude <3 <3:

 

 

Can't contribute?  Please help by getting the word out about this campaign!  Spread the word about 1001 Sundays on Facebook!

 

Special Thanks to John Mattiuzzi and Suhas Sreedhar <3

story:
"..and who are you?"

Hello! My name is Tara Abbamondi. I'm a cartoonist living in the Pennsylvania wilderness with my bearded husband and two cats. I've been drawing since I could pick up a pencil and I've been drawing comics since my high school days. I mostly posted webcomics and it wasn't until 2010 that I ventured into print comics with a one-shot called Puddles.

Puddles is the reason I’m here, actually! I’m looking to fund the third printing for the fall convention season: Tampa Bay Comic Con and SPX!

What’s it about? Well, it’s about a young girl named Maggie, who finds she has jumped in one too many puddles when she literally falls into one.

Now she's in a strange place with strange people claiming she's a savior and that she can't go home! What is she going to do? And what do her wellies have to do with this whole mess?

Also, if you'd like to know a bit more, you can read a 15-page preview on my website:

http://www.tarabba.com/gallery/puddles

 

In addition to Puddles, I’m also hoping to get funds to print another one-shot, On the Morrow.

I drew it during a self-imposed 24-Hour Comic Day just last month. It’s about a novice lumberjack, Roderick, who is jokingly left behind by his companion on an island known as the Morrow. All seems well until he starts to witness the mysteries of the island.

It’s also my unofficial love letter to all the great beards of the world. (C'mon, look at that beard!)

 What I’ll need:

 I need about $500.00 to print what I need, but here’s a breakdown of the costs.

100 copies of Puddles: $248.00

100 copies of On the Morrow: $221.00

Shipping Perks: $30.00+

Indiegogo cut: 4% or 9%

Total: ~$500.00+

 So, with your help and support I’ll be able to get both of these comics printed and ready for conventions this fall! Anything over the funding goal will go towards printing the best-looking books I possibly can.

Also, if we do reach the goal, I will update with additional incentives and bonus perks, which will include commissions, stickers, and even MORE comics! I’ll update on this further if we get closer to funding.

 

Edit: Ohmygoshwereachedthegoal!!!!!!!!!!! You guys are literally AMAZING. OK, so stretch goals? YES.

  • If we reach $800! Perk levels above and including $15 will ALL get the limited edition print, as well as STICKERS! (images forthcoming) AND a new LIMITED* perk will be added at the $25 level: Avatars! I'll draw you a twitter/tumblr/whatever avatar based on... whatever you want! Want a preview? You can check out my twitter @Tarabba! (*Limited, meaning: 10 only) UPDATE: We did it! Thank you! The new perk has been added! I'll be working on making stickers!!

  • If we reach $1,000! Puddles will recieve the spot-color treatment!!! I'm kinding of geeking out about this one, it's something I've been toying with doing for some time! The colors would be following the colors on the cover! UPDATE: WOOO!!! It's happened! Spot-color Puddles is GO! Check out the latest update for a preview of what it's going to look like!!!

  • If we reach $1,200! On the Morrow will get upgraded paper stock and cover stock!!! If we reach this goal, I will also grey tone the comic as well!

Now, onto the perks!

  • $1 A thank you in the books!

  • $7 PDF of BOTH comics

  • $15 Physical Copy of either Puddles or On the Morrow, plus a random "convention sketch", a quick drawing done with pencil and ink based on which book you get.

  • $25 Physical Copies of Puddles and On the Morrow, PDFs included. (Convention sketch included)

  • $35 Personalized Commission if you’d rather get a drawing instead of a comic, plus a digital copy of the piece. (5X7, Spot Color, subject matter is up to YOU.)

  • $45 Physical Copies of Puddles and On the Morrow, PDFs included, a limited edition print (image forthcoming!), plus a convention sketch, and a hand-drawn button pack (4)!

  • $60 Retail Perk! 5 copies of one book, or a mix of both sent to your comic shop!

  • $75 Everything listed above!

 ***All copies of either book will be signed and personalized! If you would like it plain, just let me know :)

 *****Shipping is included for ALL goals for ALL locations.

 

 

[PERK UPDATES!:]

(7/11): Instead of a B&W commissions for the $35 and $75+ level, they will now contain a spot color!! Woo!!

 

 

 

 Any Challenges?

What’s great about this particular project is that both comics are already drawn, so there won’t be a delay in getting the books to the printer! ALSO, if you will be at either TBCC or SPX, you can pick up your copies of the book there! (and I won’t have to ship it to you! Wooo! Chances are though, by that point I won’t have commissions finished, but we’ll see, if you intend on being there, let me know and I can work something out!) Otherwise, all perks will be shipped out by mid October!

 Any other ways to help out?

 I know that money is tight and will always be tight (it’s the reason I’m doing this project) so I absolutely understand if you can’t contribute. However, if you can spread the word that would be amazing and I would be eternally grateful! Twitter, facebook, Google+, tumblr! Whatever you can do, I’d really appreciate it. Thank you!

Be sure to check out the gallery as this campagin goes on! I'll be posting previews throughout!

 

FAQ:

Q: Does the levels above $15 also come with a convention sketch??

A: YES, they do! Silly me forgot to put it in there, and now it won't let me edit it. The only level that does not come with the sketch is the $35 level, because it's a commission level. Thanks!!

Q: What about shipping? I live outside of the states, can I still get comics?

A: YES! Since the books are relatively small in size and soft covered, I included the shipping within the reward tier regardless of where you live. I tried my best to estimate how much I'd be spending on shipping, so it should cover it. If I have to pay a wee bit extra that's ok.
